the oppo=
rtunity to unwash brains WRT UI testing. What I mean:

o me from a coder (in another company, though my

lar instances of the following) who shall

to paint a target on his back :-)

anonymous coder 02/08/2004 01:02 PM
> I'=
m on this project that is writing using a very-buggy,
> very-ready-any-day-=
now customized Swing-based UI. We have no tests,

 harness in place.

ill easily

> ac=
cording to our spec for all kinds of data going into the widget.
> Pretty s=
tandard TDD, wouldn't you think?

> Turns out the seriousness of this issue=
 is not wholly shared by my

> customized Swing framework:

How did we get here? Here's my etiology, YMM=
V:

Once, not so long ago, some Big Brains cogitated, and sent forth the
id=
ea (or perhaps this meme spoke through them): 

"Code-time testing is Good.=
 Cover completely, and enforce it with
build-time verification."

But from =
the trenches came the response, "The vast majority of us code
UIs--how can =
we test _those_ with xUnit tools?" Big heads scratched.
There were no UI au=
tomation tools short of monsters like WinRunner,
and manual testing is pain=
ful; both integrate with development
environments like fish ride bicycles. =
So the Big Brains said:

"Make your UIs thin, and test everything underneat=
h them. That should
Be Good Enough."

And they were, and are, right: if you=
 are very disciplined, and keep
logic and state in your UIs to absolute min=
ima, and test everything
else, you can usually get by. But

- almost no one=
's that disciplined. Bosses want a fix NOW, or you
  hafta work with UI cod=
e that's already thick, or there's some other
  reason to just stick a _lit=
tle_ bit of logic in there ... and you've
  got a bigger hole in your cover=
age.

- the Doctrine of Incomplete Testing spreads by induction.
  Coders, =
in our laziness, impatience, and hubris, tend to think:

=B7 thin =3D=3D !(=
required to test)

=B7 my Foo is a thin extension of Bar!

=B7 therefore I =
need not test it

  Unfortunately, those thin layers tend to gather togethe=
r into
  big piles of buggy crap. This is the "anti-test-infection."

- ove=
r time, the big brains were UNDERSTOOD to have said,

"Make your UIs thin, =
and test everything underneath them. That is
Enough."

  Meanwhile, thanks =
to tools built on, e.g., java.awt.Robot, now you
  CAN "go the last mile": =
you can automate and test your UIs just as
  you test the rest of your code=
, and at the same time, and using your
  fave xUnit tooling. As the capabil=
ity arose, so did the myth of its
  expendability :-(

IMHO the word needs =
to go out: test your @#$^%&* UIs, too! A thin UI
is still good ... because =
it's easier to test. But a well-designed,
untested UI is just another hole =
in your coverage. </vent>
